Award.AwardTitle: Metal-mediated Cycloaromatizations of Acyclic Tri(pi) Conjugated Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program is supporting Professor Joseph M. O'Connor at the University of California-San Diego to examine the interaction of metals with readily available polyunsaturated organic compounds in order to understand the relationship between metal-coordination mode and chemical reactivity. These investigations afford opportunities for the development of new methods for the environmentally benign construction of molecules with useful properties of interest to the chemical and pharmaceutical industry. Professor O'Connor will integrate the research and educational components of this project in order to promote education in the STEM fields by providing interdisciplinary research opportunities for college and graduate students. The proposed chemistry is expected to advance fundamental understanding of organometallic, organic, and inorganic processes.

In this research, a combination of synthetic, structural, computational and mechanistic studies will be applied to the development of new cycloaromatization reactions based on the metal-triggered reactions of acyclic tri(pi) conjugated molecules, including dienynes, trienes, and heteroatom-containing analogues. A key component of this research is the synthesis and study of hexahapto coordination of tri(pi) molecules to transition metals. These new reactions may have broad application in organic synthesis by providing alternatives to thermal pericyclic reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interaction of metals with small organic molecules has profoundly impacted society through advances in the chemical sciences.  Metals often accelerate important reactions or induce reactivity not otherwise possible, thereby opening up new routes for the efficient synthesis of targeted molecules.  With NSF support this project has begun to address the question:  What unprecedented chemical structures and associated reactivity result from the simultaneous interaction of a single metal with an acyclic array of three conjugated pi-bonds? This fundamentally important creative concept has never been experimentally investigated, despite its potential for the development of new and useful chemical reactions. Key outcomes include: 1) the synthesis, isolation, and structural characterization of the first molecules in which a metal simultaneously interacts with an acyclic array of three conjugated double bonds (e.g. 1, Figure 1); 2) the development of the first transition-metal-accelerated 6-pi electrocyclization reactions of conjugated trienes, ultimately leading to aromatic products (Figure 2); 3) the synthesis, isolation, and characterization of the first solution-stable molecules in which a metal, including an earth abundant metal, simultaneously interacts with an acyclic conjugated array of two double bonds and a triple bond (e.g. 2-Ru,2-Cr, Figure 1); 4) the discovery of a new metal-mediated mechanism for the cycloaromatization of conjugated dienynes (Hopf Cycloaromatization; Figure 3); 5) the development of the first ambient temperature C1,C6-cyclizations of conjugated dienynes leading to substituted aromatic compounds (Aitken Cycloaromatization; Figure 3); 6) the discovery of a new radical chain reaction which converts 1,4-cyclohexadiene and CDHCl2to CHDCl2and benzene, and its involvement in a new cycloaromatization of enediynes to halogenated aromatics (Figure 4). Students working on this chemistry, including students from underrepresented groups, have received valuable interdisciplinary training that positions them for making future societal contributions in industry and academics. The novel chemistry undertaken in this project advances a fundamental understanding of organometallic chemistry and establishes an important foundation for future developments in applied chemistry that will impact society in areas as diverse as pharmaceutical chemistry and materials science.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The interaction of metals with small organic molecules has profoundly impacted society through advances in the chemical sciences. Metals often accelerate important reactions or induce reactivity not otherwise possible, thereby opening up new routes for the efficient synthesis of targeted molecules. With NSF support this project has begun to address the question: What unprecedented chemical structures and associated reactivity result from the simultaneous interaction of a single metal with an acyclic array of three conjugated pi-bonds? This fundamentally important creative concept has never been experimentally investigated, despite its potential for the development of new and useful chemical reactions. Key outcomes include: 1) the synthesis, isolation, and structural characterization of the first molecules in which a metal simultaneously interacts with an acyclic array of three conjugated double bonds (e.g. 1, Figure 1); 2) the development of the first transition-metal-accelerated 6-pi electrocyclization reactions of conjugated trienes, ultimately leading to aromatic products (Figure 2); 3) the synthesis, isolation, and characterization of the first solution-stable molecules in which a metal, including an earth abundant metal, simultaneously interacts with an acyclic conjugated array of two double bonds and a triple bond (e.g. 2-Ru,2-Cr, Figure 1); 4) the discovery of a new metal-mediated mechanism for the cycloaromatization of conjugated dienynes (Hopf Cycloaromatization; Figure 3); 5) the development of the first ambient temperature C1,C6-cyclizations of conjugated dienynes leading to substituted aromatic compounds (Aitken Cycloaromatization; Figure 3); 6) the discovery of a new radical chain reaction which converts 1,4-cyclohexadiene and CDHCl2to CHDCl2and benzene, and its involvement in a new cycloaromatization of enediynes to halogenated aromatics (Figure 4). Students working on this chemistry, including students from underrepresented groups, have received valuable interdisciplinary training that positions them for making future societal contributions in industry and academics. The novel chemistry undertaken in this project advances a fundamental understanding of organometallic chemistry and establishes an important foundation for future developments in applied chemistry that will impact society in areas as diverse as pharmaceutical chemistry and materials science.
